summary.p: Gallus Albertus, a compatriot [of the Zurichers], has arrived unexpectedly but is already traveling on, so Blarer can only report generalities and hardly anything new.

- The [people of Konstanz] greatly appreciated Bullinger's news about [Jakob] Metzler and are happy to forgive him for everything. Blarer conveys a letter [from Georg] Frölich [No. 2351] received [on February 28] and a document that should be sent back with the next messenger. Blarer will read and return Bullinger's writing [“De sacramentis”].
- He hopes that Bullinger has received well the letters he sent on January 28 [No. 2335] through the butchers and on February 3 [No. 2344] through [Konrad Hofherr], as well as letter [No. 2354].
- Theodor [Bibliander] is to manage the money that Hofherr received from [Hans Peter] von Wellenberg.

div.p: Greetings. Gallus Albertus, a compatriot (Landsmann) of yours, has arrived here unexpectedly. As he is already prepared for his journey, he addresses me while I am very busy, so I can only report generalities, which I do not doubt you already know.

What you wrote about Metzler was very pleasing, and we easily forgive everything, since he has satisfied you. I am sending the letters which I received the day before yesterday from our Leto to be sent to you. Then you will also read the documents given to me here, which I ask you to return with the next messenger. I will read your book, faithfully kept, and return it to you as soon as I have read it.

I wrote to you on January 28 through our butchers, and I do not know whether you have received those letters. For they are not the ones I sent through Curio on February 3, nor the ones I sent recently through our compatriot. Therefore, see if you can find them; I would not want them to be lost.
Regarding what I mentioned about Curio, I strongly request that Theodor manage the money, 27 florins, which he received there from Wellenberg.
Commend me to the Lord Jesus Christ with your family, whom you will greet most lovingly in my words. Greetings to all brothers and friends. Farewell. March 2, 1546.
To D. Heinrich Bullinger, his venerable and dearest brother. In Zurich.
